div.p: Summer Rates will be charged from 2 May to 31 October.

For the convenience of families and others, a large portion of each ship’s accommodation has been reserved for Egypt, so that Berths can be definitely engaged at once, as if the voyage were commencing at Port Said. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company’s Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Tuesday for the present except the MONGOLIA, which is taking passengers to the Anglo-French Naval Review, and will not wait at Port-Said on 24/25 July. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before. The Fare remains as usual.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,

Bills, documentary invoices, etc, collected.

div.head: The Canal Explosion
div.p: The Chatham or the greater part of her hull with its explosive freight has vanished, the menace of dynamite has disappeared and all is over but the dredging and the press paragraphs and the litigation. Port Said, after alarming anticipations of a bombard- ment by showers of debris and a shock that would break windows and level walls, has resumed its work, perhaps as one of our correspondents remarked,somewhat disappoint ed that no damage has been done, and so far the only loss of life reported is among the fishes whose bodies are being picked upon the injured banks or found floating on the water.That there should be some damage to the banks and bed of the canal was inevitable, but it is astonish- ing that it should have proved so slight. The Asiatic bank suffered the most, the bed under the Chatham’s magazimes was depressed some 28 metres by the force of the explosion which raised it in many other places over ten feet but the banks did not collapse and the tidal wave which it was feared might rash north and south to wreck vessels and wash away the ance, to the great relief of the shipping in the harbour But the fact that the explosion was less formidable than had been expected in way diminishes the credit due to Mr. Harris and to the Government Mr. Harris, in spite of an experience of explosions that puts the record of the most uneasy monarch or the most militant nihilist in the background, was faced by a problem for the solution of which few, if any, data were available. The Aboukir explosion —a world's record till Thursday—took place far out to sea and the results of the explosion of 16 tons of dynamite under such circumstances could not afford valid conclusions as to the consequences of exploding 100 tons in the canal. Mr. Harris, however faced the situation with confidance, came out the difficult and somewhat dangerous preliminaries with success and had the grati fication of witnessing the complete success of his arrangements and the confirmation of hs optimism as to the danger of the proceeding Mr Harris has deserved well of Egypt and of the world’s shipping and we offer him congra tulations on his triumph.

The Government, on realising the situation noted promptly and vigorously. The Canada Company seconded its efforts. Soldiers ad policeman formed an effective cordon, mea sures were taken to restore railway aand telegraphic communication as soon as pos sible after the explosion and dredgers ad repairing gangs wen kept in readiness to see to work on the banks and bed of the canal. Not a single parson was killed, injured, or apparently seriously disturbed by the explo sion, the damage done to the railway was infinitesmal, to the wires slight, and the canal it seems will not be blocked for more than a week at most "All’s well that ends well" is the quotation that best suits the circumstances meantime we have to thank the Suez Canal Company and the Railways Administration for the facilities kindly offered to our represent atives and those of the many other organizations of the Egyptian Press and to mention our great debt to our Port Said correspondent enabled us to anticipate our confreres in publishing the first accurate summary of the results of the explosion.

div.head: THE GERMAN SOCIALISTS.
div.p: The members' of the German Social Demo cratic Congress in Berlin, like members of other congresses elsewhere, have been largely occupied in quarrelling among themselves. There is a rather bitter controversy raging between the old Socialists and the new. The followers of Herr Bebel, the veteran leader, are still, so to speak, waving the red flag of ’48. They believe in the doctrines of Karl Marx and Lassalle, and continue to repeat them. These moderate reformers would be perfectly content with a few trifles such as the national alisation of the land, the abolition of all private property, the confiscation of stock and shares, the extinction of private owner ship, and the conversion of the State into the supreme capitalist and sole employer of labour. On the other hand, there is a large party, in cluding most of the younger leaders of an ability, who point out that this remarkable temperate and reasonable programme, whatever its theoretical merits, is a little difficult realisation. Pending the complete reconstruc tion of society from top to bottom, they submit that it might be more politic to concentrate attention on a certain number of reforms which are somewhat less difficult of attainment These so-called political socialists are haugh tily scoffed at by the old stalwarts, who denounce them as little better than allies of the capitalist. Indeed, some of them are capitalists themselves. Nevertheless, the poli tical socialists are gaining ground with the working-men, and the old rigid group seem likely to be reduced to a comparatively unimportant faction.

The fact is the modern German social de mocratic party scarcely deserves more than half its name. It is becoming much more democratic than socialistic. It is true the socialism is cherished as a pious opinion by many German artisans, as for the matter is the case all over the world. On own trades unionists at their annual con ferences pass resolutions in favour of natio nalising some forms of property and con fiscating others as a matter of course, though most of them are themselves property owners and capitalists in a small way, with shares it co-operative societies and money in benefical clubs and savings banks. Socialism is so vague a creed that anybody may hold it without much thought of patting its tenets into opera tion. Such is the situation of a good many of the German social democrats. In practice they have become largely transformed into mere radicals. It is not so much revolution they are seeking as the redress of grievances and this concession of certain rights which have been granted to their fellows in other countries They would like, for one thing, to make constitutional government a reality. In Ger many they have a Parliament and a very wide franchise, but there is scarcely responsible government in the British sense. The executive is not under the control of Parliament, and the Parliament is not under the control of the majority of the electorate. Owing to plural voting, property qualifications, and the manner in which the constituencies are arranged, on vote has by no means one value. If it had, the social democrats would constitute more than half the Reichstag, for more votes were cast for their candidates at the last general election than for all the other parties put together.

div.head: ENGLAND AND JAPAN WORLDS RECEPTION OF TREATY ALARM IN RUSSIA
div.p: Paris, September 28 The French press has received the Anglo- Japanese treaty favourably, and it is believed that there is no reason why it should cause any ill feeling between Great Britain and Russia, and that the safety of Indo China is strengthened by the alliance of Japan with a power which is in excellent relations with France. (Reuter)
St. Petersburg, September 28. Article IV M the treaty is viewed with alarm here, and it is considered that it is open to the widest interpretation. (Reuter

Berlin, September 28. A few of the weighty German papers consi- der the treaty unobjectionable. The rest declare that it is most menacing and urge a Russo German counter alliance, of which it is believed that M. Witte's visit is the precursor. They advocate the inclusion of France in the alliance. (Reuter

St. Petersburg, September 28. The "Novce Vremya” says that the Anglo- Japanese alliance enslaves Asia, and that it is aimed particularly at Russia. It enables the allies to co operate either for the eventual annexation by Great Britain of part of Afgha- nistan or of Northern Saghalien by Japan, For these reasons Russia must counterbalance the treaty by a now alliance.
Liberal circles here welcome the alliance as tending to restrain aggressive policy, and to concentrate the attention of Russia to the improvement of the home situation. (Reuter

div.head: FRANCE AND GERMANY. AGREEMENT SIGNED.
div.p: Paris, September 28. The Agreement between Franco and Ger- many with regard to Morocco, which was signed at Paris to day, is virtually a confirma- tion of the agreement of the 9th July. The French are satisfied because it is considered to be a recognition on the part of Germany of the legitimacy of French colonial expansion. (R.)
Paris, September 28. M. Rouvier and Prince von Radolin have signed the Morocco agreement. The conference will meet at Algeciras. (Havas

div.head: THE CHATHAM EXPLOSION.
div.p: Port Said, September 28. The explosion of the Chatham blew the vessel to pieces and threw a huge column of water, sand, and debris 2,000 feet into the air. The East bank of the Canal is destroyed for a distance of 600 feet. The West bank is unda- maged It is impossible to state when the Canal will be opened for navigation, probably it will be after four days. (Reuter)

div.head: THE SUCRERIES SITUATION- DEATH OF M. DE LA BOUGLISE
div.p: Our Cairo Correspondent telephones that M. de la Bouglise, while leaving a confec- tioner’s shop in the Sharia el Manskh in company with M. Laroux at 6.30 p.m. yester- day, suddenly staggered and fell. Medical aid was unavailing, death, which is stated to have been caused by heart disease having been instantaneous. The body of M. de la Bonglise was removed to the French hospital from which the funeral will start at 4 p.m.
The sad news caused considerable excite ment on tho Alexandria bourse this morning, the shares of the Societe des Sucreries falling to 45 from 50 frs.

Sir William Wilcocks has been appointed by Judge Tuck as the third agricultural expert to replace Nourisson Bey. The Societe des Sucreries is to be congratulated on its choice since it would be difficult to find in Egypt one more suitable in every way to fill this difficult and important position.

div.head: (By Telegraph).
div.p: Cairo, Friday 11.4 p.m. M. de la Bouglise, who has been suffer- ing from arteriscelerosis for a long time, died suddenly in Sharia Suliman Pasha from an attack of angina pectoris. His death was notified by the French consul yesterday evening.

div.head: THE PRINCES AND THE DAIRA. LETTER PROM Lord CROMER.
div.p: Our contemporary “Al Lewa” publishes an important letter from Lord Cromer to H.H. Prince Ibrahim Pasha Halim concerning the action to be brought by the Princes, sons of the late Khedive Ismail, against the Govern- ment claiming the restoration of the remaining surplus of the Daira Sanich after the satis- faction of all the creditors of the said admi- nistration, as being heirs of the former owner the late Khedive. One of the claimants, Prince Ibrahim Pasha Halim according to our con- temporary, wrote to ask Lord Cromer’s opinion on his claim. Lord Cromer's reply left no doubt as to his opinion ; he expressed his agree- ment with the view of the Coutentieux and after drawing the attention of Prince Ibrahim to the opinion he had given in 1878 when serving on the Commission of tho Egyptian Debt, vix., that the Daira properties had been illegally acquired, that their acquisition was prejudicial to the interests of the country and that the Khedive should restore the properties illegally obtained, he added : — “ I still maintain my opinion and regret to inform your Highness that not only am I unable to support your claim but that should the Egyptian Government be disposed to admit it, I would be obliged to protest in the most effective fashion in the interests of the Egyptian people and taxpayers.”

This excellent and uncompromising answer appears to have greatly annoyed our confrere, Mustapha Pasha Kamel, who calls upon the Egyptian public to show their resentment at the affront offered to the sons of the late Khedive Ismail and to support the demand of the princes for the restoration of their rights. We imagine that the Egyptian public will prefer Lord Cromer's advice to that of the "Nationalist leader” and Turkish pasha.

div.head: CHEMIN DE FER DE L’ORIENT.
div.p: We are informed that the number winning the first prize in the Chamin de Fer de l’Orient lottery is 41698, provided there is no error due to faulty transmission by telegraph.

div.head: ASILE KAISER WILHELM.
div.p: A concert was given on Tuesday afternoon at the Asile Kaiser Wilheim under the patronage of the vice-consul of Germany by Mme Meyer and her pupils and was very largely attended. Mme Tonelli, sister of the well-known Alexandria musician Professor Lombardo, also assisted, playing a duet with Mme Meyor which was very much appreciated and in which both ladies showed great musical talent. MM. Astorre and Michel Mabardi sang together in an excellent manner, and M- Amodio greatly pleased the audience by his rendering of a selection from the opera Aida which he played on the violin. M. Egon Mabardi recited excel- lently. We must also mention Miles Lea Ponta, Eveline Tonelli, Mario and Olga Philippides, all of whom performed their part of the pro- gramme most faithfully and showed a wonderful technical knowledge of music, although they are still quite children.

div.head: THE FAYOUM MURDER.

Mataloti’s cook, and his ghaffir have been arrested with ten other arabs, who are believed to have aided and abetted the actual murderers, if they were not guilty themselves. The inquiry continues.

div.head: THE CHATHAM EXPLOSION MR. HARRIS' GREAT SUCCESS WATER ASCENDS 500 YARDS. (From our Port Said Correspondent.)
div.p: Port Said, Thursday 2 p.m. I am now able to send you full details of the world's record dynamite explosion, which, as I telegraphed you as soon as the wires were in working order at 1.30 p.m., was successfully performed, and if I may be allowed to say so, reflects the greatest credit upon Mr. Harris. The divers, who bad been specially selected on account of their previous experience and because they bad been down all over the ship on former occasions, were on the scene last night as well as tags and material, so that all should lie in readiness for laying the mines at the first streak of dawn. Mr. Harris, his two assistants, Mr. Schmitt and Mr. Plata, Lieute- nant Cunningham and the interpreter, left here at 5 a.m. in the Albatross arriving at Ras el Esh at 5.45 a.m. where they dropped Mr. Plum who proceeded to kilometre 15.5 to prepare the north end of the firing wires and cut everything else. At Ras el Esh the party took on board two skilled telegraph wire workers and the vessel left at once, towing the dabsbeah, with the charges on board, after them, to the Chatham. The mines were made up in huge bolsters of sail canvas and each had two submarine detonators in them with about eight feet of cable attached, to which the submarine cable was to be connected.

Arriving alongside the Chatham the divers were at once sent down to open the hatches ready for lowering the mines into place, whilst Mr. Harris himself proceeded to attach the connecting wires. These wore each of 100 yards long and were, at the proper time, led ashore and fixed on to Nos. 2 and 4 telephone wires on the posts on the canal bulk. The joints were made most care fully, and in about half an hour the 300 lb. mine for No 1 hold was ready for lowering. The mine was put into a canvas hammock, the rings of which served as slings, All was now ready, and the charge was care- fully raised and put into a boat, which, in its turn, was taken under the derrick head with which the dahabesh had been specially fitted. The piece of cable which was to connect the mines in Nos 1 and 3 holds being attached, and the joint being covered with guttapercha, the mine was lifted by the winch and gently lowered to the divers who were standing on the trunk deck waiting for it, some 14 feet below the surface. Great care and gentleness was exercised in the lowering of the charge as it would have been absolutely fatal had the mine received the least shock, and after some little time taken in manipulating the awkward ‘baby’ it eventually, some 15 minutes later, lay resting on the cases of dynamite in the vessel's hold. To avoid any shock, the rope by which the mine was lower- ed, was then cut, and the dahabeah with its greatly relieved operators on board proceeded to the next hold to which the divers had already gone, whilst the cable which would complete the circuit between the two charges was enrolled from a boat. Before going any further the first shore line was sent away and tied to a post as it was not safe to connect in any way with shore lines until all the work on the Chatham had been finished.

The divers then opened np hold No. 3 whilst Mr. Harris went on with his joints and con- nections, if anything more carefnlly than before. All being ready at eight o’clock, the second charge was lowered in its hammock and placed in dose proximity to the case of detonators, which had been the Canal Company’s "bate noir” in the early days of this dangerous and most anxious problem. By 8.15 a.m. all was ready, and the boats were sent away to the tugs waiting some little distance north of the ship, and these vessels at once left for Port Said at top speed. Mr. Harris and his little select group then went about their final shore connections, whilst Mr. Tillier telegraphed to Port Said to hoist the signal which would tell the people of that town that in an hour, vix., at 9.50 a.m., the wires would be fired. In a few moments the wires were connected and the party left for the firing point where were assembled Mr. Tillier, Mr. Coallant, Mr. Doyen, Mr. Schmid, and Mr. Perrier, no one else being allowed within the cordon of sol- diery which had been drawn at an early hour at kilometre 3.1.

Arriving at the firing point, kilometre 12.52, the experts proceeded to test the wires, the result of which would prove whether the explo- -ion would occur or not, for were there the very least fault in the wires or connections the galvanometer would show at once the use- lessness of proceeding further, and the need fir at once lifting the charges anew and making new joints and examinung the whole length of three miles of wire. The galvsnomoter register- ed a force of 11, and with a sigh of great relief the party lit up pipes and cigars to await the appointed time knowing that the ship would go up the moment the twist exploder lever was put down.

At 9.45 a.m. the first wire was screwed on to the exploder and in four minutes the other wire was treated similarly, whilst the little party stood round, watches in hand, waiting the word from Mr. Tillier on whose time the order to hoist the Port Said signal was made. Precisely at 9.50 a.m Mr. Harris quietly took out his handkerchief and firmly grasped the lever, thrusting it down with all his force. Istant- aneously, and before he had taken his hand off the lever, a shock was felt as if the ground had been struck heavily in the near vicinity, and an immense column of water, sand, debris, stones, and pieces of iron ascended and con- tinued to ascend for five seconds, getting blacker every moment as the fragments in- creased in number. The column appeared at first like a huge fountain, and as it grew it assumed the form of an immense black tree with great branches. Up it went with great rapidity, growing in height, density, and volume, till 15 seconds after the explosion it had attained a measured height of 560 yards and had spread the width of the canal twice over. The water boiled and foamed, being scattered the while in a hundred ways all across the canal. The report, which resembled that of a 4.7 gun at a distance of say 500 yards, reached the firing point 16 seconds after the lever was put down and considerably surprised me by its feebleness. I think most of the other untechnical watchers, like me, expectated a much louder report and several of them remarked on the weakness of both sound and shock. Thirty-five seconds after the charges were fired, the greater part of the debris had fallen, but for fully two min- utes the sir was full of mist and the water above the remains of the unfortunate ship continued to boil up violently and tear up the banks of the canal. Whilst awaiting the train, which was in readiness with some 50 guests on board at kilometre 8, the party amused itself in trying to discover the extent of the damage to the canal, but this distance was too great and nothing was certain. No tidal wave accompanied the explosion though a current with a veloc- ity of about two miles an hour ran past kilometre 12 and back some few minutes after; nor did any debris reach the spot—both of which points Mr. Harris had declared himself sure of.

The train arriving shortly after, the party proceeded slowly fearing accidents to the wires at Ras el Esh where telegraph line staffs were stationed to get their lines at once in order. Slowly and carefully we went on to kilometre 18 and there stopped, finding the line smother- ed in grass, reeds, trees, telegraph wires, frag- ments of iron etc., and the country inundated, but rapidly drying, for some 1,009 yards round the spot.

With great excitement the guests and Mr. Harris' party left the train and crossed the fresh water canal by the bridge which had been erected the previous day, find- ing the fresh water canal intact, though very muddy and thick with weeds, grass, and trees. Arriving on the maritime canal bank walking became difficult. Wires, posts, pieces of ship's plates, beaxs, and frames were sticking up in all directions and the surface of the ground was under water in places, and muddy in the extreme.

No telegraph posts were actually down but all the wires were off the posts, lying about everywhere and covered with a thick coating of oxide. Along the African bank, which had not suffered in the least except for numerous and immense holes in the ground where the masses of water had descended, all was desolation and wreck.

In a circle of about 600 yards radius thous- ands of pieces of the ship lay in confusion and all the country had been covered deeply in water. Dead fish were plentiful and were secur- ed by the Arabs on the train.

The Railway staff at once proceeded to their survey but found no damage beyond a few loose bolts and the telegraph parties started at once to repair the damage to their lines. The Asiatic bank presented a truly awful sight with a huge hole driven into it of some 70 yards wide and 250 long, strewn with wreck- age and coke in a fine powder.

The fore end of the ship as far as abaft the engine room had completed disappeared, the mainmast in small pieces lay resting on what little remained of the poop and no signs were visible of anything else belonging to the ship except the hundreds of pieces with which the East bank and its environs were strewn.

Immense fissures were cut in all directions, the wreck lay everywhere in thick mud, half a mile way great pieces of engines and plates were standing sentry over the surronnding waste of marsh and desert. All was black from the coke dust and smelt strongly of nitro- glycerine, the fumes from which were contin- ually rising from what was left of the vanished but famous Chatham.

A hurried survey with the lead line was made before the officials and Mr. Harris’ party left for Port Said after their mostt anxious and tiring day. At the spot where the fore end of the ship lay -yesterday there were 22 metres of water. The depths varied from 20 to 15 metres and in the middle of the canal where originally 9 metres covered the bottom, only 6, or even less, could be measured. The shock had excavated hundreds of tons of mud and sand and deposited it towards the African shore.

Railway traffic was resumed this afternoon by 3 o'clock, whilst the State telegraph lines were repaired and in use by half past one and those of the Canal Company only half an hour later. Great relief is felt at the little damage which has been done and Port Said especially congratulates itself upon the escape of its fresh water supply from any interuption, as this was regarded as more than possible. It cannot be definitely said for how long the canal traffic will be delayed but I hardly think that a clear passage will be obtained for another ten days. I shall, however, be able to tell you more when I have learnt the results of the soundings which are, at the time of writing, being taken. Tags, divers, sounders, and dredgers are all on the spot and the Canal Company officials are displaying the same activity which they have shown ever since the boat caught fire on the 5th inst Mr. Harris, upon whom the respon- sibility of the carrying out of this experiment lay, mast indeed be pleased with the result of his work, and fully deserves all the con- gratulatory terms which I hear on every side, whenever his name is mentioned, which is not seldom.

div.head: (From Another Correspondent.)
div.p: A remarkable example of the terrors of the unknown has been affurded by the scare created in Port Said by the blowing up of the Chatham which was successfully effected shortly before ten o'clock. Shops in the town remained unopen, people left their houses in fear that they would collapse, and in a variety of other ways showed their dread of the effects of the explosion. And yet when it did take place, even the sound of it in the still morn- ing air was so dull that it might well have passed unnoticed by any one not expecting anything out of the common. Seated on a chair placed on the frail covering of the water tank on the roof of the Eastern Exchange and exposed to the foil glare of a burning sun, with eyes or glass fixed on one spot, the time of waiting, seemed long. The signal flag was hoisted on the Canal Company’s offices a little before nine o'clock. The hour struck, all of us, (about a dozen) were gazing intently on the distant landscape, but the minutes went by, the chimes told the quarter-past, half-past,and a quarter to ten without the least sign of anything having happened. But directly after wards two or three steam launches were seen to be rapidly coming in the direction of Port Said and it was evident that the moment for which we were eagerly waiting was at hand. At seven minutes to ten a huge gray column slowly rose and spread out like a tree, disap- pearing again in the space of a few seconds, almost before the dull muffled sound of the explosion was heard. This column rose to an enormous height impossible to estimate, and consisted of water and sand, though it looked more like smoke. Not the slightest earth tremor could be detected and the water below us was not in the least disturbed.
I understand that little more than I have described was experienced by those who went by the special train and who were unable to get any nearer than five miles from the scene of explosion.

Altogether the damage done has been far below even the minimum estimate and it seems to be only a question of the removal of the wreckage of the ship and the time in which this can be effected, before the traffic of the canal can be resumed. The present estimate is that it will take about three or four days only.

div.head: ( By Telegraph. )
div.p: Port Said, Friday, 9.22 a.m. The following were present at the electric generative station at kilometre 12 yesterday:— iMM. Coallant, Tillier, Diyeo, Jasserand, Schmitt, Lieutenant Cunningham, Mr. Harris and his two assistants. The first wire was connected at a quarter to ten exactly, the second at 9.49 a.m. and the explosion took place in less than one second after Mr. Harris had pressed the lever of the twist exploder. In one second the column of water had risen to a height of 100 yards, in eight seconds it measured 400 yards and in twelve seconds a height of 550 yards was reached. Then the debris was seen to rise in great masses, and pieces of iron weighing more than a ton were thrown into the air as high as half a mile. The mixture of water, sand, and debris continued to rise for thirty five seconds. It is anticipated that further explosions will be necessary to complete the destruction of the vessel. Prompt measures were taken by the Canal Company officials towards repairing the damage done. At two o’clock sounding and repairing gangs, engineers, divers, and dredgers were hard at work and careful surveys were being made. The length of time for which the canal traffic will be interrupted cannot be estimated accurately until the report which the engineers make as a result of their survey is to hand, but it is generally anticipated that it will be a week. Mr. Harris, however, considers that ships will be able to pass through in safety in less than a week's time.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: H.H. The Khedive remained at Montazah to-day and attended Friday prayers at the Montazah Mosque.
H.E. Coles Pasha, C.M.G., inspector general of the Prisons Department is returning to Egypt by the Bibby liner Cheshire leaving Marseilles on the 6th proximo.
Sir Elwin Palmer will arrive in Cairo on Tuesday next from England.
Mr. K Speir, the newly appointed secretary general of the State Railways, will arrive in Cairo from England on the 4th October.
Mr. John Perret has been appointed surve- yor of the Zifta circle of irrigation at a salary of L.E. 18 per month.

The P. and 0. Persia leaving Marseilles to- day for Port Said is bringing out a good number of well known residents amongst whom are Sir Malcolm Mellwraith, H.E. Crookshank Pasha and Mrs. Crookshank, Schalch Bay, Mr. and Mrs. C. Snow, Mr. and Mrs. Hooker, Captain MoMnrdo, Mr. and Mrs. Noel Beyts and the Misses Beyta, etc.

div.head: EGYPTIAN SHARE MARKET (From our Financial Correspondent).
div.p: London, September, 22. The dominating factor during the earlier part of the week has again been the money market and the question as to what action would be taken by the dimeters of the Bank of England at their meeting yesterday was dis- cussed. Opinions were fairly evenly divided respecting a rise in the Bank rate but three discount houses which accepted six months Bank bills at 2 1/2 have proved correct in their anticipations rather than those which declined them under 3 2/5, for no change was made of the directors yesterday, the weekly return showing a stronger position then was expected. The Bank rate therefore remains for the present at 3 %. The opening of the markets yesterday shows that this was pretty well anticipated before midday with the consequence that there was a more cheerful tendency all round, and prices generally hardened. Consols, which we quoted last week at 89 13/15. have been up again to 89 7/8, and today close at. 89 9/25 This upward tendency has permeated all other gilt- edged securities, and they may be said to be on the advancing tack again.

Foreign Government bonds gained renewed strength on Continental buying. Japanese stocks were in special requests on a report which comes from a creditable source that Japan is already rewiring large amounts of money in respect of the Manchurian railway. The new loan is quoted at 4 7/8 Russian bonds have been firmer, it being reported that M. Witte has had an interview with Messrs Rothschild. Baron Hottingner, and Herr Pisehel. of Berlin, for the purposes of raising a "Peace" loan. The situation is considered favourable for the launching of this shortly, and it is believed that the loan will be offered in France, Germany, Belgium and Holland, but not the United States.

In the Home Railway market, increased traffics, the result of the steady improvement in trade, have produced a hardening tendency in prices. The amalgamation of the Great North of Scotland Railway with the Highland Railway, which is now on the tapis, and will probably be consummated era long, is looked upon favourably. The Amarican market has been stronger throughout the week, and Pacifica have taken the lead again. Not with- standing that the bulls have been taking profits, the shares have steadily risen, and it is predicted that they will shortly reach 200.

There is little to report regarding, move- ments in the Egyptian share market generally. Stocks have been quite inactive since our last, with, if anything, a slightly easier tendency. It is expected that the new Bank of Abyssinia, is about to make its appearance under the auspices of the National Bank, and, although nothing definite is yet known of the exact nature of the issue, it is favourably spoken of. It is believed that the last issue of New Natio- nal Bank shares was with connected with the Abyssinian venture. National Banks close to-day 27 7/8 and Agricultural Banks 14 5/8.

The only news to hand since our last with reference to the Societe de Sucreries et de la Raffinerie d'Egypt is that the accounts show a loss of L.F.213,000 over a period of ten months to the end of August last. In this is not included a deficiency of £920,000 which must be added to the former sum in the event of the Company being declared responsible for the bills drawn by M. Cronier. Daira Sugar shares are still quoted 4 3/4 and Daira Sanieh 27 7/8. Some business has been taking piece in the 1/2%. Preference shares of Walker and Meima- rachi which are quoted at 3 3/4 to 4 1/4. , In the mining market, the week has ended with a slightly firmer tendency in prices, and in the Rhodesian market Bankets are well maintained at £4. Mr. Garthwaile’s report, whilst not entirely optimistic, is looked upon with more or less favour as giving a tree version of the real state of affairs in the Banket section.

In the Egyptian mining market, Nile Valleys have slightly eased off since last week, and are now 1 3/16. ‘'Vigilant," in "Truth," says regard- ing these:—“Nile Valleys are being favourably influenced by a cable announcing that good rich ore has been located at the 200 feet level, the extent and value of which has not yet been ascertained. This is pleasant reading bearing in mind the discouraging developments of the past month or so.”

New Egyptians have also been easier at 1, whilst 15/ is the beet price for Egyptian Mines Exploration. Egyptian Estates and Egyptian Trust are also quoted at lower figures. United African Exploration, the mother company of several Egyptian ventures, have improved in price to 1 1/4.

div.p: Nous nous empressons da publier la répome qu'a bion voulu donnor M. Debourg, admini* trateur de la société, à la demando dca action nairas : Monsieur le Directeur de “l'Egyptian Gazette." Lie "Groupe d’Actionnairea” qni, par la voie do votre honorable journal, deinaude l'explics tiou du retard daus la publication du Bilan o‘ daus la convocation de l'Assemblée Générale de lEgyptiau Salt & Soda Cy. Ltd. aurait obtenu de la direction de la Sooiété laréponso immédiate A sa question, s’il lui avait (ait l’honneur de la lui poser directement Ce n’en est pats moins aveo plaisir que je m'em pros su de lui donner satisfaction. Les précédents bilans de la Société avaient été établis etpiésentés aux Assemblées Géné- rales aux dftes suivantes :

On voit par ce tableau que jusqu'à présent la périodicité des bilaus a été inégale, — ce qu'il n'est pas dans l'intention du Conseil do continuer — mais un inconvénient non moins sérieux résidait dans le fait qu'aucune des dates auxquelles ils ont été clôturés ne corres- pondait à la fin d'une campagne d'affaires, en ce qui concerne toat au moins l'exploitation des usines.

Un élément essentiel de tont bilan d'indus- trie est l’Inventaire des usines et des magasins et il est généralement reconnu que l'époque 1. plus favorable pour dressor un inventaire do cette nature est la fin de la campagne et non le milieu. Pour l'industrie des huileries eu Egypte, c est le 31 Août, date admise poor la clôture de la saison cotonnière.

Le Conseil d’Administration éln par la der- nière Assemblée Générale Londres, convaincu de la nécessité de faire concorder le commence ment et la fin dos exercices sociaux avec les dates d'ouverture et de clôture des campagnes commerciales d Egypte, a décidé qu'à l’avenir les bilans embrasseraient U période de douze mois comprise entre le 1er Septembre d’une année et le 31 Août de la suivante et que lo premier bilan à présenter à l'Assemblée Géné- rale serait arrêté au 31 Août 190>.

Ce bilan est en préparation. Le travail qn'il comporte oette année se trouve exceptionnelle- ment compliqué de l'unification des oomptes de la Société des Huileries et de l'Egyptian Sait and 8oda Cy., consécutive à la fusion et de l’ouvertnre an 1er Septembre d'une compta- bilité apropriée an nouvel état de choses.

Le Conseil d'Administration apporte à co travail tonte la diligence voulue et pe négligo rien pour abréger, autant que possible, l’impa- tience des actionnaires. Veuillez agréer, Monsieur le Directeur, l'es- surance de mes sentiments les plus distingués. Eca Debocbo.

div.head: AUX SUCRERIES
div.p: Noue extrayons du "Progrès” l'entrefilet suivant : Contrairement à ce qui a été dit par un £ nos confrères, MM Leroux, de la Bouglisr, Poutrel, Pangalo et Minci n'assistaient pas à l’entrevue que Harari pacha a eu hier matin aveo l’hon. A. J. Davoy, aux Sucreries. Ces Messieurs n'avaient, en effet, aucune qualité pour prendre part à la réunion. M. Ninci, en particulier, bien quesimplementdémissiounairr, doit être considéré comme effectivement li- cencié, ayant été mis 8n demeory ou de donner sa démission ou de recevoir une lettre de ren- voi. Nona apprenons de la source la plus auto- risée, que cette grave mesure a été prise à l'égard de M. Ninci par suite de détournement depièoes, dont il so serait rendu coupable : un document important serait encore dans les mains de M. Ninci. La lettre par laquelle l'hon. Davey a accepté la démission de l'ancieu ad ministratenr fait d'ailleurs toute réserve sur sa gestion.

div.head: UPPER NILE PROBLEMS. BY SIR WILLIAM GARSTIN. ( Continued. )
div.p: During July, then, daily increasing dischar- ges are arriving at Khartoum from both the Blue and White Niles, and to these are added the volume of the Atbara, north of the junc- tion. These three rivers combined cause the annual flood rise in Egypt. In August, the effect of the two great eastern flood-feeders becomes much more pronounced, and in this month occurs one of the most important and most interesting phenomena of the entire Nile system. At this period the flood discharge of the Blue Nile increases very rapidly, and attains to a volume some ten times as great a* that brought down by the White Nile. Tho Blue Nile now plays an exactly similar part (but upon an infinitely larger scale, with regard to the White Nile) to that which I have already described the Sobat as doing to the White Nile above the junction. As soon as the Blue Nile flood exceeds a certain volume at Khartoum, it Holds back the waters of the White Nile entirely - ponding them up and forming an immense reservoir, which floods the White Nile valley for several hundred kilometres up stream of the junction of the two rivers. This ponding up is maintained until the discharge of the Blue Nile again falls below the volume in question, which generally occurs in September. As soon as this happens, the impounded water in the White Nile is set free, and passes on to the north. As the Blue Nile discharge further decreases, its place is taken by that of the White Nile water. In conse- quence of the water stored in the reservoir, the discharge of this last river increases stead- ily until the end of the year. When the Sobat also fills, the water held up in the smaller reservoir—up stream of the junction with the White Nile- passes down the latter channel and helps to maintain the supply. In the month of November, when the Sobat discharge has shrunk to small dimensions, the equatorial lake water, passing down the Bahr el Gabel, again becomes the main source of the White Nile supply, but the water hold up in the two reservoirs above mentioned is so considerable in quantity that, throughout the early winter months, the volume actually passing Khartoum is considerably greater than that which comes down from the lakes after having passed through the great marshes.

I hope I have succeeded in making the above comprehensible. To those who do not know the Nile, and who have not studied its discharges, it is difficult to explain this wonder- ful arrangement, by which these rivers auto- matically compensate one another, so that at the time when the one system is passing on a large volume of water, the other is storing up its discharge, and when the former begins to decrease in volume the stored water takes its place and makes good the deficiency.
I must now say a low words regarding the water requirements of Egypt and of the Sudan.

Many people, I think, know that in Egypt there are two systems of irrigation—the one known as “basin," and the other as “perennial’ irrigation. The former system, which dates from the days of the Pharaohs, consists of turning the Hood-water over the land, then draining it off, and sowing a crop upon the slime thus deposited. In the latter system water is given throughout the year, but only in such quantities as required, and is our. trolled in an elaborate system of canals. By this last method the more valuable crops such as cotton and sugar-cane, are raised, and land perennially irrigated increases in value over that watered as “basin" to an extra ordinary extent. Consequently, all the effort of the irrigation service in Egypt are directed to devising some means by which—during this month previous to the flood, when the river would be naturally at its lowest—the supply of the Nile may be materially increased and the area of land perennially irrigated mater ially augmented.

To begin with the water requirements of Egypt. The latest return assess the total cultivable area at eight millions of acres, of which about one million consists of waste land From this total it will be safe to deduct half a million acre; as representing land unfit for cultivation. Another half million acres border ing the edge of the western desert south of Cairo will aways be reserved as basin. This reduces the area to seven millions acres. Of this, four million acres, at present, receive peronnial irrigation, and by the end of 1908, the conversion of the basins will raise this total to four and a half millions. Deducting this figure, there remain two and a half mil lion acres to be provided for. Experience has shown that one milliard (1,000 millions) of cubic metres of water stored will suffice for the summer irrigation of half a million acres of land. Consequently, these two and a half million acres will require a storage of five milliards of cubic metres of water.

The question before us is —how are these five milliards to be obtained ? The Assouan dam, if raised, will provide for another half million acres ; but, even suppos- ing this be done, there will still be four milliards of cubic metres to be eventually provided.

The depression in the western desert— known as the Wadi Rayyan—has been pro posed as a reservoir. It is very possible that it may one day be made use of for this purpose but, owing to its situation, it would probably be best reserved until such time as the question of reclaiming and irrigating the shallow lake which border the northern delta shall become one of urgency.

It is probable that storage reservoirs, of sufficient capacity to store the required four milliards, can be constructed in the Nile valley, somewhere between the second and the sixth cataracts. This cannot, however, be stated with certainty until the survey of the cataracts —now in progress—shall have been completed. Meanwhile, supposing it were possible to construct each reservoirs, it would be im- possible to fill them with water, unless the winter supply in the river, brought down from the south, be largely increased. Those responsible for irrigation in Egypt are well aware that under present conditions, in a year of low supply, it would only just be possible , to store another milliard of water above the Assouan dam, if raised as proposed. I say this would be just possible, but in doing so the extreme limit of water available for storage would be reached, and undoubtedly the winter navigation of the Nile, between Assouan and Cairo, would suffer very considerably. In order, then, to find the extra water required, some means must be found of increasing the flow of the Upper Nile during the periods of winter, spring, and early summer.
Now, as to the irrigation requirements of the Sudan.

The area of cultivable land in the Sudan may almost be termed unlimited, as a far larger area exists than could ever be irrigated by the Nile, supposing that its waters were entirely devoted to such a purpose. The irrigation limits, then, are those due to the water avail- able, the physical features of the country, and the density of population. Large tracts, how- ever, are blessed with a bounteous rainfall, and much of the area is so scantily populated that it may be left out of the present calcula- tion. It will be amply sufficent, for all present needs, to select those tracts which, from their favourable situation, appear to be most likely to bring in a return for money expended. Among such areas are the lands of the north- eastern Ghezireh—namely, the land lying be- tween tho two Niles. To these may he added the tracts bordering the cast bank of the Blue Nile. Tho extent of laud that can be irrigated must depend entirely upon the amount of water that the proposed new works can secure for the summer irrigation of this country, but, if a few million acres can be thus benefited, ample provision will have been made for the wants of the next generation of Sudanese.

In a recent report upon the basin of the Upper Nile I recommended that all summer water available in the Blue Nile should be made use of for the Sudan alone, while the waters of the White Nile should be reserved for Egypt and the river valley between Khartoum and Assouan. I ven- ture to think that this recommendation is a sound one,and it certainly logical. The richest ands in the Sudan—namely, those I have alluded to above—can only be watered by means of the Blue Nile. The White Nile owing to its feeble elope, is not suitable for any large irrigation schemes, and, moreover, the lands adjoining it are not nearly so rich as those upon the Blue Nile. As it its im- material to Egypt from whence is water shall be derived, of maintain that the White Nile must be need to a carrying channel for con- veying water to that country, while the Blue Nile water must be reserved for the benefit of the countries adjoining it, which can bf irrigated by no other means, The projects, with the proposed expenditure, may then be divided into two categories: those relating to the White Nile, which will benefit Egypt; and those on the Blue Nile, which will benefit the Sudan alone.

I will discuss the schemes regarding the White Nile first, as they are not only larger but infinitely more difficult to pronounce de finitely upon than those contemplated for tLi Blue Nile. In order to comprehend what ii proposed it will be necessary to study thi accompanying map. ,

It will be Been that the Bahr el Gebel, or White Nile, leaves the cataract region and enters the marshes, near the Belgian port of Rajaf, and down stream of the Pedden Rapids For the purposes of this note th:s point may be considered to be Gondokoro, the Uganda frontier station, which is situated a few miles to the north.

Between Gondokoro-and Bor—a distance of 100 miles—the river is bordered by wide swamps, but does not enter the great marshes in which the sudd blocks occur, until the latter point is reached. Consequently, although im- provement of the channel between the two places will be requisite, in order to enable it to carry the extra water required, the work will be comparatively straightforward, and, in any case, no alternative line exists. This portion of the scheme is, of course, common to all projects for improving the White Nile. What is re quired here is the widening and deepening of the channel, upon a sufficient scale, and the closing of all the spills by which the river water is wasted in the marshes.

North of Bor, however, there are severs alternative proposals, and it is here that the real difficulties commence. I should mention that what is called Bor consists merely of a collection of Dinka villages, but this place becomes important from the point of view of our schemes as being the last point where the high bank—on the east — abuts upon the river before the latter loses itself in the great swamps. I have said that, in all our schemes for increasing the Egyptian water supply, we must turn to the White Nile Although at the sources of this river Nature has provided water in abundance she has tantalisingly erected an effectual barrier to its being made use of, in the shape of the vast marshes, through which the river struggles for nearly five hundred miles, and in which it loses more than half its volume. All our aims must then be directed to devising some means by which this waste may be avert ed, and by which the lost river may be enabled to pass through the swamps in undiminished in volume.

I have mentioned that the first reach of tl river—from Gondokoro to Bor—has a length 109 miles. The projects for further re- modelling the Upper Nile most all lie within the reach between Bor and the junction of the Sobat with the White Nile—a distance of some 444 miles, as measured upon the river itself.

A farther reference to the map will show that, at 366 miles below Bor, the Bahr-el-Ghazal meets the Bahr el Gebel—the junction a shall- ow sheet of water known as Lake No, and called by the Arabs "Moghren el Buhur." or the Meeting of the Rivers. Also, it will be observed that, from below Bor, somewhere in the marshes, a loop of the Bahr-el-Gebel runs to the east, conveying the White Nile between Lake No and the Sobat junction. This loop is known as the Bahr-el Zaraf, or Giraffe River, and is formed by numerous spills from the Bahr-el-Gebel. In its upper course this river is difficult to trace, but lower down it has a well-defined channel. It is not easy to make the above explanations clear and comprehensible ; the nomenclature of these rivers is so perplex ing. I hope, however, that the map will render assistance in this respect, and, in order to understand what is proposed, it is indispen- sable that these names should be borne in mind.

The problem, then, before us is—how best to improve the river, between Bor end the Sobat junction, so as secure that the summer supply passing the former point from Gondo- koro shall be delivered et the Sobat juno- tion with as small amount of loss as is possible.

Obviously, the natural way to do this, and that which would occur to everyone first visiting these rivers, or studing their course upon the map, would be to take np and im- prove either the Bahr-el Gebel or the Bahr- el-Zaraf— widening and deepening the one or the other, by means of dredgers, and, at the same time, closing all its outlets into the marshes, so as to render it capable of carry- ing the required supply. I mention that neither of these channels is at present at all capable of doing this. The Bahr-el-Gebel, which is the main stream and by far the larger of the two, can, under present conditions, only carry one third of the future required supply. The Bahr-el-Zaraf, again, has a very much smaller section, and is even less fitted for what is required. Neither of these streams has any banks at all, and, were any extra water turned into them, it would only spill over into the marshes and be lost by evap- aration, and by the absorption of the water- weeds which cover this area.

In my last year’s report, to which allusion has already been made, I described an alterna- tive scheme which, if feasible, is to my mind, a great improvement upon either of the others. The original idea for this scheme was first suggested to me by Mr. J. S. Beresford, late Inspector-General of Irrigation in India. I will describe it.

Between Bor and the Sobat junction, the Nile takes a great bend to the west. A straight line drawn between these two points, upon a meridian, would not only shorten the distance between them very considerably, but would pass through dry land, leaving the entire swamp area well to the west of it. The project then is to out a channel—between Bor and the Sobat junction—sufficiently large to take the entire future summer discharge of the Upper Nile, but not large enough to take in the flood water. This last is an important point I will explain why.

When I first passed through the sudd in the year 1900, and for several years after, I was under the impression that—although in sum- mer (when the river is low) the waste through the marshes was excessive—daring flood, when the volume is large, the mass of the river water passed through the swamps and found its way into the White Nile, down-stream of them, with but little diminution. Consequen- tly, all my earlier projects for improvement were based upon the idea that it was neces- sary so to widen the river, through the marshes, as to render it capable of carrying the entire flood discharge passing Gondokoro. It was not until the sudd had been removed, and I was able to obtain a series of consec- utive measurements of the discharges, above and below the obstacle, that I realised that my first impression had been erroneous, and that the greater the volume of water arriv- ing at the south end of the marshes, the larger is the proportion of loss in that is- suing from their northern extremity. Farther, it was not until two years ago that I grasped the real solution of the problem—namely, that these marshes provide a magnificent natural escape for the flood-water, and that all oar efforts should be devoted to encour- aging it to spread over them, and be thus wasted and evaporated, while the precious si name r water is confined to a well-defined and satisfactorily constructed channel of its own, and conveyed to the north with com- paratively little waste. All the present sche- mes are based upon this idea, which has im- mensely simplified the problem to be solved.

Now, in the case of the remodelling of the existing channels—the Bahr-el-Gebel and the Bahr el-Zaraf—there are certain disadvantages and difficulties, to which I will afterwards allude, in the way of so constructing either channel that it may carry the entire summer water supply, and yet permit of the flood- water escaping into the marshes. In the case of the proposed new cut, from Bor to the Sobat, such difficulties do not arise.

A masonry regulator (with a look for navi- gation) would be built at the head of the new channel, while another masonry regulator would be constructed across the river bed at Bor. The new cut would thus assume the cha- racter of a large artificial canal, and, by means of the regulators, the most perfect control over its discharge, and over that of the river, would be secured. Thus, in winter and in summer, when it was desired to pass down all the water in the river to the north, the head regulator of the new channel would be completely opened, and the regulator acroes the .Nile would be closed. At this time no water would past into the marshes. In flood the reverse would be the case. The Nile regulator would be fully opened, so that the flood water could pass through and lose itself in tha swamps, while the head of the new channel would be so regulated upon that only so much water would be permitted to pass down it as was required for navigation. It must be remembered that, at this season, no water is required in the White Nile from the south, as the Sobat discharge, during the flood months, takes the place of the Bahr el Gebel water and arrests the latter entirely.

Undoubtedly this project is a most attractive one, and to my mind—always supposing that farther detailed studies shall not prove it to be impracticable— it is the soundest of all those under consideration for impro- ving the Upper Nile. It requires no technical knowledge to understand and appreciate how great would be the advantages to be gained by the construction of such a diversion of the river. The present long winding channel through the marshes would be replaced by a straight cut, through dry land, very much shorter than the existing line. This cut would be under complete control, owing to the regulator at its head. There should be comparatively little loss throughout its length, as the velocity would be considerable, and its alignment would take it well to the east of the swamps. The earth derived from the excavation of the channel would form wide banks on either side, which would form good lines of communication, even during the rainy season, and upon which the trans continental telegraph line, sod even the railway—should this last ever be constructed—might with advantage be placed. No obstruction would be caused to the drainage east of the channel, which would flow, most probably, into the Khor Filus, a drainage line running parallel to the new cat. Lastly, the flood water should not enter the new channel at all—beyond the amount actually required for navigation—but would spread all over the marshes and be lost by evaporation. In this way a perfect control over the Upper Nile could at all seasons be obtained.

I give here the approximate distances bet- ween Gondoro and the Sobat junction by the three respective schemes I have mentioned. I ought to say that the length of the proposed new channel, between Bor and the Sobat, is, approximately, 210 miles. These figures show how great is the advan- tage, as regards distance, to be gained by the new channel.

I do not consider that any of the objections that I have seen brought forward against this project militate seriously against its sound- ness. My own objection to it, and that which, to my mind, may cause its abandonment, is the probable cost of such a work. This mast necessarily be very great, and it is quite pos- sible that it may prove to be so excessive as to be prohibitive. Until the levelled survey has been completed it is useless to speculate upon this point, as it is impossible to prepare any estimate which can be, in the slightest degree, an accurate one. It may be that the longitud- inal slope of the country between Bor and tho Sobat may prove to be so feeble that a very large cross section of channel will be entailed, and consequently an immense cube of excava- tion. On the other hand, it may be that the great gain in distance secured by this channel may compensate for this extra cube, as com- pared with the other projects. We cannot yet say, and must await the detailed survey.

Another objection that occurs to me as regards the new channel, though not so serious as the foregoing, lies in the difficulties of its execution, and the time that the work might take to complete. I hope, however, that, with the progress made in recent year in the way of perfecting types of hydraulic dredgers and steam excavator*, it may be found that such difficulties may not prove to be so great ax they at present appear. It must be understood that, whatever may be the project finally selected, machinery must be made use of in its execution, as the employment of hand labour upon a large scale in these regions is quite out of the question. (To be continued.)
